msItem.textLang: Undetermined language written in ogham script

support.desc: The rock face bears carvings of circles which are internally subdivided into quadrants by two perpendicular straight lines. The carvings are reminiscent of the encircled cross motif, but that is probably coincidental. The lower circle utilizes a natural fissure to extend the incised internal diameter line running NW to SE to arrow-headed terminals at each end. A second circle adjacent to the NE has a similar extended internal diameter line running E to W, the W with an arrowhead terminal, the E with what appears to resemble a studded crosshead and a possibly separate small circled motif added. The third circle adjacent to the NE has a similar extended internal diameter line, its W terminal with what seems to be possible cuts of a cross base, its E terminal ending with an arrowhead (Scotland's Rock Art Project).

supportDesc.condition: An incised rock face of exposed and much weathered schist which bears prehistoric cupmarks and other carvings, some of which are reminiscent of an ogham inscription of unusual form.

layoutDesc.layout: The alleged ogham markings are located a little to the left of the lowest of the three circle carvings on a stem-line that appears to have been incised on the rock face and reads upwards from the bottom.

handDesc.handNote: The purported ogham letters appear to have been pocked.

origin.origPlace: Killin, Perthshire, Scotland 56.496944, -4.385556 National Grid Reference: NN 5325 3641
origin.origDate: Late Neolithic to Early Bronze Age (c.4000BC to 1500BC)

history.provenance: An incised rock face, consisting of a sloping area, 2.44 m x 0.76 m (8' x 2 1/2'), behind Duncroisk farmhouse, 1/4 mile NE of the farm entrance. The rock-face is situated beside a routeway between two valleys, at a burn, in an elevated position with a spectacular view. The setting is typical of prehistoric rock art. The carvings at Duncroisk, which resemble encircled crosses, were first mentioned in 1950/1952, and the ogham was first mooted in 2021 following a photogrammetric model by Andrew Powell.
In situ. Visited and recorded by the OG(H)AM team in May 2025.

app.note: The OG(H)AM project visited the site in May 2025 and were able to confirm that, though the marks are consistent with the rules of ogham script, they are probably not an ogham inscription but likely of prehistoric date in keeping with the surrounding cup-marks.

div.p: Some of the circle carvings have stems which extend above and below, with a triangular ‘roof’ which resembles a feather-mark (though pointing in the wrong direction). In one case, there are a few strokes extending from the stem in a manner which has a general resemblance to ogham but cannot be read as a meaningful text. It is somewhat similar to the ogham on a small bone from Cahercommaun, Co. Clare. On balance, however, the lightness of the incision makes it quite unlike extant ogham inscriptions and it is rejected.
